message: Data engineering is my passion.
author: Eve

message: I learn in this letter that Don Pedro of Arragon comes this night
author: leonato

message: to Messina.
author: leonato

message: He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off when I left him.
author: messenger

message: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?
author: leonato

message: But few of any sort, and none of name.
author: messenger

message: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full
author: leonato

message: numbers. I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honour on a
author: leonato

message: young Florentine called Claudio.
author: leonato

message: Much deserved on his part, and equally remembered by Don Pedro.
author: messenger

message: He hath borne himself beyond the promise of his age, doing in the figure
author: messenger

message: of a lamb the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better bettered expectation
author: messenger

message: than you must expect of me to tell you how.
author: messenger

message: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of it.
author: leonato

message: I have already delivered him letters, and there appears much
author: messenger

message: joy in him; even so much that joy could not show itself modest enough
author: messenger

message: without a badge of bitterness.
author: messenger

message: Did he break out into tears?
author: leonato

message: In great measure.
author: messenger

message: A kind overflow of kindness. There are no faces truer than those
author: leonato

message: that are so washed; how much better is it to weep at joy than to joy at
author: leonato

message: weeping!
author: leonato

message: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the wars or no?
author: beatrice

message: I know none of that name, lady: there was none such in the army
author: messenger

message: of any sort.
author: messenger

message: What is he that you ask for, niece?
author: leonato

message: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.
author: hero

message: O! he is returned, and as pleasant as ever he was.
author: messenger

message: He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged Cupid at the
author: beatrice

message: flight; and my uncle’s fool, reading the challenge, subscribed for
author: beatrice

message: Cupid, and challenged him at the bird-bolt. I pray you, how many hath he
author: beatrice

message: killed and eaten in these wars? But how many hath he killed? for, indeed,
author: beatrice

message: I promised to eat all of his killing.
author: beatrice

message: Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much; but he’ll
author: leonato

message: be meet with you, I doubt it not.
author: leonato

message: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.
author: messenger

message: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it; he is a very
author: beatrice

message: valiant trencher-man; he hath an excellent stomach.
author: beatrice

message: And a good soldier too, lady.
author: messenger

message: And a good soldier to a lady; but what is he to a lord?
author: beatrice

message: A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuffed with all honourable
author: messenger

message: virtues.
author: messenger

message: It is so indeed; he is no less than a stuffed man; but for the
author: beatrice

message: stuffing,—well, we are all mortal.
author: beatrice

message: You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a kind of merry war
author: leonato

message: betwixt Signior Benedick and her; they never meet but there’s a
author: leonato

message: skirmish of wit between them.
author: leonato

message: Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last conflict four of his
author: beatrice

message: five wits went halting off, and now is the whole man governed with one! So
author: beatrice

message: that if he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let him bear it for a
author: beatrice

message: difference between himself and his horse; for it is all the wealth that he
author: beatrice

message: hath left to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his companion now? He
author: beatrice

message: hath every month a new sworn brother.
author: beatrice

message: Is’t possible?
author: messenger

message: Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as the fashion of
author: beatrice

message: his hat; it ever changes with the next block.
author: beatrice

message: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.
author: messenger

message: No; and he were, I would burn my study. But I pray you, who is
author: beatrice

message: his companion? Is there no young squarer now that will make a voyage with
author: beatrice

message: him to the devil?
author: beatrice

message: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.
author: messenger

message: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease: he is sooner
author: beatrice

message: caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs presently mad. God help the
author: beatrice

message: noble Claudio! If he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a thousand
author: beatrice

message: pound ere he be cured.
author: beatrice

message: I will hold friends with you, lady.
author: messenger

message: Do, good friend.
author: beatrice

message: You will never run mad, niece.
author: leonato

message: No, not till a hot January.
author: beatrice

message: Don Pedro is approached.
author: messenger

message: Balthasar and Others.
author: messenger

message: Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your trouble: the
author: don pedro

message: fashion of the world is to avoid cost, and you encounter it.
author: don pedro

message: Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of your Grace, for
author: leonato

message: trouble being gone, comfort should remain; but when you depart from me,
author: leonato

message: sorrow abides and happiness takes his leave.
author: leonato

message: You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this is
author: don pedro

message: your daughter.
author: don pedro

message: Her mother hath many times told me so.
author: leonato

message: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?
author: benedick

message: Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child.
author: leonato

message: You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this what you are,
author: don pedro

message: being a man. Truly the lady fathers herself. Be happy, lady, for you are
author: don pedro

message: like an honourable father.
author: don pedro

message: If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not have his head on
author: benedick

message: her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.
author: benedick

message: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior Benedick:
author: beatrice

message: nobody marks you.
author: beatrice

message: What! my dear Lady Disdain, are you yet living?
author: benedick

message: Is it possible Disdain should die while she hath such meet food
author: beatrice

message: to feed it as Signior Benedick? Courtesy itself must convert to disdain if
author: beatrice

message: you come in her presence.
author: beatrice

message: Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I am loved of all
author: benedick

message: ladies, only you excepted; and I would I could find in my heart that I had
author: benedick

message: not a hard heart; for, truly, I love none.
author: benedick

message: A dear happiness to women: they would else have been troubled
author: beatrice

message: with a pernicious suitor. I thank God and my cold blood, I am of your
author: beatrice

message: humour for that. I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swear
author: beatrice

message: he loves me.
author: beatrice

message: God keep your Ladyship still in that mind; so some gentleman or
author: benedick

message: other shall scape a predestinate scratched face.
author: benedick

message: Scratching could not make it worse, and ’twere such a face
author: beatrice

message: as yours were.
author: beatrice

message: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.
author: benedick

message: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.
author: beatrice

message: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and so good a
author: benedick

message: continuer. But keep your way, i’ God’s name; I have done.
author: benedick

message: You always end with a jade’s trick: I know you of old.
author: beatrice

message: That is the sum of all, Leonato: Signior Claudio, and Signior
author: don pedro

message: Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all. I tell him we shall
author: don pedro

message: stay here at the least a month, and he heartly prays some occasion may
author: don pedro

message: detain us longer: I dare swear he is no hypocrite, but prays from his
author: don pedro

message: heart.
author: don pedro

message: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.
author: leonato

message: Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled to
author: leonato

message: the Prince your brother, I owe you all duty.
author: leonato

message: I thank you: I am not of many words, but I thank you.
author: don john

message: Please it your Grace lead on?
author: leonato

message: Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.
author: don pedro

message: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?
author: claudio

message: I noted her not; but I looked on her.
author: benedick

message: Is she not a modest young lady?
author: claudio

message: Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for my simple
author: benedick

message: true judgment; or would you have me speak after my custom, as being a
author: benedick

message: professed tyrant to their sex?
author: benedick

message: No; I pray thee speak in sober judgment.
author: claudio

message: Why, i’ faith, methinks she’s too low for a high
author: benedick

message: praise, too brown for a fair praise, and too little for a great praise;
author: benedick

message: only this commendation I can afford her, that were she other than she is,
author: benedick

message: she were unhandsome, and being no other but as she is, I do not like her.
author: benedick

message: Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me truly how thou
author: claudio

message: likest her.
author: claudio

message: Would you buy her, that you enquire after her?
author: benedick

message: Can the world buy such a jewel?
author: claudio

message: Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this with a sad
author: benedick

message: brow, or do you play the flouting Jack, to tell us Cupid is a good
author: benedick

message: hare-finder, and Vulcan a rare carpenter? Come, in what key shall a man
author: benedick

message: take you, to go in the song?
author: benedick

message: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on.
author: claudio

message: I can see yet without spectacles and I see no such matter: there’s
author: benedick

message: her cousin and she were not possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much in
author: benedick

message: beauty as the first of May doth the last of December. But I hope you have
author: benedick

message: no intent to turn husband, have you?
author: benedick

message: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn to the contrary,
author: claudio

message: if Hero would be my wife.
author: claudio

message: Is’t come to this, in faith? Hath not the world one
author: benedick

message: man but he will wear his cap with suspicion? Shall I never see a bachelor
author: benedick

message: of threescore again? Go to, i’ faith; and thou wilt needs thrust thy
author: benedick

message: neck into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away Sundays.
author: benedick

message: Look! Don Pedro is returned to seek you.
author: benedick

message: What secret hath held you here, that you followed not to Leonato’s?
author: don pedro

message: I would your Grace would constrain me to tell.
author: benedick

message: I charge thee on thy allegiance.
author: don pedro

message: You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a dumb man; I would
author: benedick

message: have you think so; but on my allegiance mark you this, on my allegiance:
author: benedick

message: he is in love. With who? now that is your Grace’s part. Mark how
author: benedick

message: short his answer is: with Hero, Leonato’s short daughter.
author: benedick

message: If this were so, so were it uttered.
author: claudio

message: Like the old tale, my lord: ‘it is not so, nor
author: benedick

message: ’twas not so; but indeed, God forbid it should be so.’
author: benedick

message: If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it should be otherwise.
author: claudio

message: Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well worthy.
author: don pedro

message: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.
author: claudio

message: By my troth, I speak my thought.
author: don pedro

message: And in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.
author: claudio

message: And by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.
author: benedick

message: That I love her, I feel.
author: claudio

message: That she is worthy, I know.
author: don pedro

message: That I neither feel how she should be loved, nor know how she
author: benedick

message: should be worthy, is the opinion that fire cannot melt out of me: I will
author: benedick

message: die in it at the stake.
author: benedick

message: Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of beauty.
author: don pedro

message: And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will.
author: claudio

message: That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that she brought me up,
author: benedick

message: I likewise give her most humble thanks; but that I will have a recheat
author: benedick

message: winded in my forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick, all
author: benedick

message: women shall pardon me. Because I will not do them the wrong to mistrust
author: benedick

message: any, I will do myself the right to trust none; and the fine is,—for the
author: benedick

message: which I may go the finer,—I will live a bachelor.
author: benedick

message: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.
author: don pedro

message: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord; not with
author: benedick

message: love: prove that ever I lose more blood with love than I will get again
author: benedick

message: with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a ballad-maker’s pen and hang
author: benedick

message: me up at the door of a brothel-house for the sign of blind Cupid.
author: benedick

message: Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou wilt prove a
author: don pedro

message: notable argument.
author: don pedro

message: If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot at me; and he
author: benedick

message: that hits me, let him be clapped on the shoulder and called Adam.
author: benedick

message: Well, as time shall try: ‘In time the savage bull
author: don pedro

message: doth bear the yoke.’
author: don pedro

message: The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible Benedick bear it,
author: benedick

message: pluck off the bull’s horns and set them in my forehead; and let me
author: benedick

message: be vilely painted, and in such great letters as they write, ‘Here is
author: benedick

message: good horse to hire,’ let them signify under my sign ‘Here you
author: benedick

message: may see Benedick the married man.’
author: benedick

message: If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.
author: claudio

message: Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in Venice, thou
author: don pedro

message: wilt quake for this shortly.
author: don pedro

message: I look for an earthquake too then.
author: benedick

message: Well, you will temporize with the hours. In the meantime,
author: don pedro

message: good Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato’s: commend me to him
author: don pedro

message: and tell him I will not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath made
author: don pedro

message: great preparation.
author: don pedro

message: I have almost matter enough in me for such an embassage; and so
author: benedick

message: I commit you—
author: benedick

message: To the tuition of God: from my house, if I had it,—
author: claudio

message: The sixth of July: your loving friend, Benedick.
author: don pedro

message: Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your discourse is sometime
author: benedick

message: guarded with fragments, and the guards are but slightly basted on neither:
author: benedick

message: ere you flout old ends any further, examine your conscience: and so I
author: benedick

message: leave you.
author: benedick

message: My liege, your Highness now may do me good.
author: claudio

message: My love is thine to teach: teach it but how,
author: don pedro

message: And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn
author: don pedro

message: Any hard lesson that may do thee good.
author: don pedro

message: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?
author: claudio

message: No child but Hero; she’s his only heir. Dost thou affect her, Claudio?
author: don pedro

message: O! my lord,
author: claudio

message: When you went onward on this ended action,
author: claudio

message: I looked upon her with a soldier’s eye,
author: claudio

message: That lik’d, but had a rougher task in hand
author: claudio

message: Than to drive liking to the name of love;
author: claudio

message: But now I am return’d, and that war-thoughts
author: claudio

message: Have left their places vacant, in their rooms
author: claudio

message: Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
author: claudio

message: All prompting me how fair young Hero is,
author: claudio

message: Saying, I lik’d her ere I went to wars.
author: claudio

message: Thou wilt be like a lover presently,
author: don pedro

message: And tire the hearer with a book of words.
author: don pedro

message: If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,
author: don pedro

message: And I will break with her, and with her father,
author: don pedro

message: And thou shalt have her. Was’t not to this end
author: don pedro

message: That thou began’st to twist so fine a story?
author: don pedro

message: How sweetly you do minister to love,
author: claudio

message: That know love’s grief by his complexion!
author: claudio

message: But lest my liking might too sudden seem,
author: claudio

message: I would have salv’d it with a longer treatise.
author: claudio

message: What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
author: don pedro

message: Look, what will serve is fit: ’tis once, thou lov’st,
author: don pedro

message: And I will fit thee with the remedy.
author: don pedro

message: I know we shall have revelling tonight:
author: don pedro

message: I will assume thy part in some disguise,
author: don pedro

message: And tell fair Hero I am Claudio;
author: don pedro

message: And in her bosom I’ll unclasp my heart,
author: don pedro

message: And take her hearing prisoner with the force
author: don pedro

message: And strong encounter of my amorous tale:
author: don pedro

message: Then after to her father will I break;
author: don pedro

message: And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.
author: don pedro

message: In practice let us put it presently.
author: don pedro

message: How now, brother? Where is my cousin your son? Hath he provided
author: leonato

message: this music?
author: leonato

message: He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tell you strange
author: antonio

message: news that you yet dreamt not of.
author: antonio

message: Are they good?
author: leonato

message: As the event stamps them: but they have a good cover; they show
author: antonio

message: well outward. The Prince and Count Claudio, walking in a thick-pleached
author: antonio

message: alley in my orchard, were thus much overheard by a man of mine: the Prince
author: antonio

message: discovered to Claudio that he loved my niece your daughter and meant to
author: antonio

message: acknowledge it this night in a dance; and if he found her accordant, he
author: antonio

message: meant to take the present time by the top and instantly break with you of
author: antonio

message: it.
author: antonio

message: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?
author: leonato

message: A good sharp fellow: I will send for him; and question him yourself.
author: antonio

message: No, no; we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself: but I
author: leonato

message: will acquaint my daughter withal, that she may be the better prepared for
author: leonato

message: an answer, if peradventure this be true. Go you and tell her of it.
author: leonato

message: Cousins, you know what you have to do. O! I cry you mercy, friend; go you
author: leonato

message: with me, and I will use your skill. Good cousin, have a care this busy
author: leonato

message: time.
author: leonato

message: What the good-year, my lord! why are you thus out of measure sad?
author: conrade

message: There is no measure in the occasion that breeds; therefore the
author: don john

message: sadness is without limit.
author: don john

message: You should hear reason.
author: conrade

message: And when I have heard it, what blessings brings it?
author: don john

message: If not a present remedy, at least a patient sufferance.
author: conrade

message: I wonder that thou (being as thou say’st thou art, born
author: don john

message: under Saturn) goest about to apply a moral medicine to a mortifying
author: don john

message: mischief. I cannot hide what I am: I must be sad when I have cause, and
author: don john

message: smile at no man’s jests; eat when I have stomach, and wait for no
author: don john

message: man’s leisure; sleep when I am drowsy, and tend on no man’s
author: don john

message: business; laugh when I am merry, and claw no man in his humour.
author: don john

message: Yea; but you must not make the full show of this till you may do
author: conrade

message: it without controlment. You have of late stood out against your brother,
author: conrade

message: and he hath ta’en you newly into his grace; where it is impossible
author: conrade

message: you should take true root but by the fair weather that you make yourself:
author: conrade

message: it is needful that you frame the season for your own harvest.
author: conrade

message: I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace;
author: don john

message: and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to fashion a
author: don john

message: carriage to rob love from any: in this, though I cannot be said to be a
author: don john

message: flattering honest man, it must not be denied but I am a plain-dealing
author: don john

message: villain. I am trusted with a muzzle and enfranchised with a clog;
author: don john

message: therefore I have decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had my mouth, I
author: don john

message: would bite; if I had my liberty, I would do my liking: in the meantime,
author: don john

message: let me be that I am, and seek not to alter me.
author: don john

message: Can you make no use of your discontent?
author: conrade

message: I make all use of it, for I use it only. Who comes here?
author: don john

message: What news, Borachio?
author: don john

message: I came yonder from a great supper: the Prince your brother is
author: borachio

message: royally entertained by Leonato; and I can give you intelligence of an
author: borachio

message: intended marriage.
author: borachio

message: Will it serve for any model to build mischief on? What is he for
author: don john

message: a fool that betroths himself to unquietness?
author: don john

message: Marry, it is your brother’s right hand.
author: borachio

message: Who? the most exquisite Claudio?
author: don john

message: Even he.
author: borachio

message: A proper squire! And who, and who? which way looks he?
author: don john

message: Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.
author: borachio

message: A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?
author: don john

message: Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty room,
author: borachio

message: comes me the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand, in sad conference: I whipt
author: borachio

message: me behind the arras, and there heard it agreed upon that the Prince should
author: borachio

message: woo Hero for himself, and having obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.
author: borachio

message: Come, come; let us thither: this may prove food to my
author: don john

message: displeasure. That young start-up hath all the glory of my overthrow: if I
author: don john

message: can cross him any way, I bless myself every way. You are both sure, and
author: don john

message: will assist me?
author: don john

message: To the death, my lord.
author: conrade

message: Let us to the great supper: their cheer is the greater that I am
author: don john

message: subdued. Would the cook were of my mind! Shall we go to prove what’s
author: don john

message: to be done?
author: don john

message: We’ll wait upon your Lordship.
author: borachio
